What a novel concept, to make a family film that has humor for kids AND adults without being overly pandering or unnecessarily innuendo-filled. Hollywood filmmakers often think these two things are mutually exclusive (even in stuff I liked like this year's Penguins of Madagascar), but Paddington has the scent of the best of Pixar, wearing its heart and its humor on its sleeve, often simultaneously. Skillfully directed and impossibly enjoyable, it will leave you grinning from ear to ear.The story is fairly rudimentary: an uptight but well-meaning family welcomes in an eccentric guest (the form of a bear cub) and all their lives are turned upside down. You don't go to this movie for surprising story beats or unpredictable twists; instead, go for the bright colors and immense fun. Lead human adults Bonneville and Hawkins are fantastic, treating their roles with as much care as they might for any prestige job they may get. Antagonists Kidman and Capaldi are hilarious adversaries, cartooning-up their performances to wonderful pitches. Even the musical score is filled with oodles of charm.The film infamously had a fairly troubled production, with a revolving door of cast and crew members. Luckily, you would never know this by the film itself, a fantastic little nostalgia trip that harkens some of the best elements of Steven Spielberg, Chris Columbus, and Wes Anderson. Made with more style and care than most child-geared films, the sweet hilarity stems from inventive comedic-action and some spectacularly well-drawn characters. Tasteful, distinctive, and completely entertaining, Paddington is a family comedy that the WHOLE family can, not just endure but, really enjoy.
Despite the predictable ending, the film is funny and entertaining with colourful and clever sets and whatsmore, the bear is oh so sweet and cute everyone would love him.

A fresh air in January movies. I never read the books nor watch the series, but I love how the story runs. Although not all the Browns were very welcoming, soon they develop a strong feeling towards Paddington. So do I....

It's taken me far too long to get round to reviewing this since I saw it so my reflections on it are limited ... so suffice to say it's magnificent. Like all of us who grew up on Paddington there was nervousness at a precious childhood memory being revisited; I needn't have worried. It's a loving, committed, beautifully produced all-age film. I say all-age advisedly; this is not a children't film. A children's film will only be enjoyed by children. Paddington will be richly enjoyed by anyone with a heart, a soul and a sense of humour. We laughed a lot throughout the film; and the film's message of welcoming the different and challenging 'other' person into your heart and home community is unmistakably presented without ever ramming it down the throat. The performances are whole-hearted and engaging; the bear himself us hypnotically funny and perfectly presented. Just see it and love it.

I went to see this cartoon with my girlfriend, because we thought that it was from the creators of Ted and that hence it would be hilarious. But the cartoon turned out to be just a kid story.The story begins in South American jungle, where a British adventurer meets a couple of talking bears. At once they become friends. Many years later the bears' nephew launches upon a journey to London (because his uncle dies and his aunt is going to home of elderly bears) in a quest to find the adventurer. The little bear gets lost on the Paddington station (That is why later he was given the name Paddington), but a nice-looking family picks him up and helps him in his mission. Turns out, that the adventurer had been expelled from the geographical community when he returned from the jungle because he did not bring any trofeys from his journey (like stuffed bears) and that his daughter is now on a quest to correct her father's mistake by killing the little bear. Of course, the good prevails in the end.I personally enjoyed the plot though. It is thought-through and is suprisingly original for such cartoons. I would really recommend you to watch it with your kid, for all the kids around us were amazed. They were laughing and yelling etc. Beautifully-drawn, this cartoon is only of interest to kids of age 12 and younger.
Paddington was an absolutely perfect portrayal for the big screen. Big enough for theatres, but still as charming as ever. Marmalade has never looked so delicious.

[slight spoilers] Paddington is a really beautiful film. Taking a lot of inspiration from successful modern classics (several shots are humorous recreations of recognizable film moments), Paddington is light, friendly, and fun.The movie takes several opportunities to show off London as a modern metropolis where the white people are as busy and eccentric as you'd expect from any Brit, while the colored people are free to smile and play music! Stereotypes aside, Paddington demonstrates the stunning modernity that's tucked in with London's tidy, elegant past. It's very much an advertisement for your tourist dollars. This is all fine and dandy, however, because the movie is brilliantly shot. The cinematography is continuously exciting while the editing moves the film at a brisk pace the whole way through. Add this to the beautiful score and you have a very well produced film.All in all, I walked away happy, but not entirely satisfied. I still felt bad for Paddington - he still had his aunt to write and he had found a home in London, but surely something more than marmalade is needed for closure. This bear experienced a lot of loss. I'm hoping for more adventures with Paddington in the future, but I'm not holding my breath. For now, it's good to see that London can still find love for strangers, even if they are bears. :)

I loved this movie! The character animation is wonderful, and the story is cute and childlike. I was actually surprised to see Nicole Kidman up on the screen - I admit I hadn't really looked that closely at the cast before seeing the movie. She does a great job as her character, but to me she stuck out as the very recognizable face in a cast of characters played by actors I was not familiar with from other movies. It's not her fault, of course, if I've seen her other work; she's terrific in this movie.The other human characters, all played by actors I didn't immediately recognize, all manage to be individually interesting, which is a great thing to say for a movie. You would almost like to follow each of the children, their parents, even their slightly weird bachelor next-door neighbor around for a day to see what they do with themselves. It would have been easy enough to just have the cute CGI bear in there and leave the human characters as not much more than furniture so the sets don't look bare - this movie does not suffer that problem.Some adults might take issue with a few parts which have dreamy, imaginative qualities to them - for example, Paddington steps right through a screen showing a film of his home in Darkest Peru and it's like he's home again. In another part, some decorative trees painted on a wall first lose the (painted-on) flowers blooming on them, and then the flowers sprout again. I don't think kids are confused by this kind of stuff; I think this sort of subtle imaginative flourish is something they can both understand and embrace. I asked my first-grader about those two specific parts, and she had exactly the same reaction to Paddington walking through the screen that I had - at first, we thought Paddington actually had walked through the screen, then we realized he was thinking about his home. (The flowers on the tree went over her head, but she seems to have just let it slide.)There aren't a huge number of movies I would pay to see again - this one, given a good reason (like to share it with another child or someone else who would appreciate it) I would pay again to see this one.

Exactly what it needs to be, Paddington bear is earnest, kind-hearted, charming, and - I'm man enough to say it - adorable. In fact, I'll go as far as saying the film is "totes adorbs". Endlessly creative in form, writer/director Paul King finds fascinating and inventive ways to show this old story in a new and fresh way. It looks absolutely fantastic, and the bears look so life like you'll find yourself second guessing whether there really was a talking bear on set.But what King does so well in modernizing this story is that he never loses the heart of the film. With a great performance from Ben Whishaw, King is able to portray Paddington as a sweet character who is just looking for his place in the world. Instead of undercutting the charm and wit of the film by poking fun at its own concept of a talking bear, King embraces the storybook nature of the film, and it pays off for him in spades. The film's unique look will transport children to the world of Paddington bear in a way that will feel like its ripped from a bedtime story.King is so perfect at dealing with every aspect of the film that nothing seems to go unnoticed. Every character is fleshed out and has a rewarding sub plot, and the supporting cast is just perfect. From Nicole Kidman's deliciously evil villain to Sally Hawkins loveable mother trying her best to keep her family together to Hugh Bonneville as the helicopter parent who learns to embrace a little bit of chaos, every performance hits every note perfectly. They're well-equipped to handle the physical comedy, the one-liners, and the emotional moments, and so these people feel like family that you grow to love.There's even some great subtext throughout the film about accepting strangers to your country and allowing them to find a place of their own. There are a few jokes about colonialism/imperialism that I found absolutely wonderful and subversive for a children's film. It's a movie that is much smarter than it needs to be, and I'm so thankful that it is. Because Paddington doesn't just tug on your heart strings, but it also engages with your mind in a way not many children's films can. If you have young children please do not miss out on this, you'll enjoy it just as much as they will.

Paddington is a very old school family film, which is a good thing. It doesn't meddle with juvenile humor or cheap gags--save for maybe a brief wall-scaling incident. But it remains honest to its purpose of bringing the beloved book series to life on the big screen without sacrificing its integrity for a "21st century touch".Yeah, sure, it's completely predictable, but we really don't care. Paddington is just too lovable and this story is just so sweet and innocent. And there aren't really any concerning plot holes, which are common in films of this nature. I did notice that it borrows heavily--whether intentionally or not--from 1992's Beethoven. However, that film was so long ago that Paddington still receives it's own identity from having such a great backstory and a charming lead. Most of all, the movie never tries to be anything that it's not. It's classy and refreshing.Twizard Rating: 96

A cute and surprisingly touching family movie that attempts to overreach the capabilities of its script to become an instant classic."Paddington" is the latest in a long line of adaptations based on the lovable little bear from the Children's book series that began in the 1950s. This one stars the likes of Sally Hawkins, Hugh Bonneville, Peter Capaldi, Nicole Kidman, and Ben Whishaw as Paddington and tells the story of the childhood favorite bear who, after being forced out of his homelands of darkest Peru, heads to the city of London in search of an explorer that had discovered and taught his aunt and uncle years earlier. Upon arriving in the city he meets the Brown family who take him in much to the chagrin of Mr. Brown (Bonneville), a well meaning yet over protective risk assessment specialist. The family all eventually warm up to him and help him search for the explorer in hopes of finding closure for him, meanwhile however there is a vindictive female taxidermist searching for Paddington for unknown reasons.Going into this film I knew little more about the property than there was a television show from the 80s about it and I hadn't followed much of the films production. I was however aware of the recent last minute voice casting switch (Colin Firth out in favor of Whishaw) made within the last six months and that didn't really give me much hope. Nonetheless I went in with an open mind and I have to admit....I was pleasantly surprised. I'm not going to say it was an amazing movie, I can't even say it was anything that I will ever have the desire to see again (though I wouldn't be opposed), but it was a cute and enjoyable way to spend 95 minutes of my day. Through the utilization of beautiful transitions and movements director Paul King directs the movie in a way that greatly spotlights the magic in the world and goes a long way in making the film what it is. However, it is this style of attempting to create a magical instant classic that goes furthest in exposing the formulaic script riddled with cliches. From the typical 4 member family where the wife and youngest child take an instant liking to the outsider protagonist while the father and elder child are slower to come around to the outsider, to the vengeful villainous plot it is hard to call this films core script anything more than template B in structure. The film does feature a high amount of both clean adult and clean family humor in it and unlike many family films released in the modern era, and I would be lying if I said I didn't find myself laughing and smiling through out the film. Overall, while successfully overcoming what seemed to be countless things working against it and providing a thoroughly enjoyable experience Paddington suffers from a cliche script and fails to become the classic it so desperately attempts to be.

Not having grew up with the original children's television show, I went into this film with fresh eyes, and I must say, you definitely do not have to be familiar with this story to enjoy it. Out of nowhere we receive a January film that jumps right from the screen and puts a smile on your face. Once a bear loses his father and is abandoned by his mother, he but fend for himself and find a new home in London. Meeting a family whom he begins to love, this picture deals with family loves and hardships throughout, while still managing to keep a consistently humorous tone. I must say, for most of this film, I was loving every second, until Nicole Kidman "kidded" it up a bit too much. She was fun to watch in the film, but her storyline felt the most tired and boring. Overall, "Paddington" is probably the best January film you will see this month and I highly recommend it. What a pleasant surprise!

My husband and I are well past childhood but with no grandchildren to bring along. We LOVED Paddington! I had thought it might be formulaic and trite. I truly believe that the British sometimes do things better and with class. Case in point: PADDINGTON. I read the books as a child and was excited for this live action adaptation. One the surface, the movie looks like your average family film with a cute CGI bear getting into trouble. While the movie has some comedic moments, it is hardly slapstick. Paddington himself is a cute, charming, and polite bear that is very likable the moment you see him. The CGI is amazing and as far as talking bears from Peru go, he is the most realistic bear to be put on screen. The story is surprisingly sweet with the human cast doing a fine job. Nicole Kidman plays the villain, but you never feel like she is just another villain. There is backstory and her motives make sense for her character. Paddington's adopted family are also have their quirks. Each member has their own problems and I like how they are not shown as a perfect family. Paddington himself is well-voiced by Ben Whishaw, who gives the bear a curious, yet respectable voice. The movie doesn't shy away from some serious moments and when you realize how it relates to Paddington, it makes you engross in this little bear's journey to find a home. I enjoyed this movie very much. It has a little something for the kids and the adults and it is one of those films that the whole family can watch. Along with the witty one-liners, creative direction and a title character who is just darn charming, I had a smile on my face from start to finish. This is the type of children's film that doesn't have to rely on fart jokes, slapstick, and crude humor to be entertaining.Grade: A

"Paddington" is the newest cinematic adaptation of the book about the cute, loveable, talking bear who stows away on a cargo ship from Peru to find a family and a new life in jolly old England. A woman (Sally Hawkins) sees him at the train station and agrees to take him in until they can find a suitable home for him. In the meantime, a taxidermist for the Natural History museum (Nicole Kidman) is hunting Paddington down to try to turn him into a stuffed exhibit. The movie is very wholesome and heartfelt on the whole. It feels like a complete movie with natural-flowing humor that doesn't force slapstick, punchy one-liners or sell out for cheap laughs. It has a very old-fashioned approach to moviemaking, but many of Paddington's shenanigans will still elicit laughs from the audience. This is a cute family film that people of all ages can enjoy in every sense of the word. Even though the movie is somewhat predictable and formulaic, I did not feel this approach detracted from the film's execution. Though I feel the relationship between Paddington and the Brown family progressed unusually fast, I think it had the right amount of authenticity to show the positive impact the bear had on their lives, and how they managed to soften the uptight father. Paddington is a very likeable character, and the fact that he is freaking adorable doesn't hurt his case with audiences either. It is surprising to see a film of this caliber in January, and I hope the rest of the year brings successes like this film ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- A-

Funny, heartwarming, and entertaining to all, Paddington is a great film for all to enjoy.

In spite of enjoying myself thoroughly during the screening, I cannot quite sign on to a full-throated endorsement. My reservations are quite specific, and may not bother other people (though I wish they would). Namely, I find it inexcusable, in 2015, even if adapting a book written in 1958, when cultural attitudes were different, that one should continually - especially if one belongs to a former colonial power like Great Britain - use the phrase "darkest Peru" over and over again, without irony, to describe the country of origin of the titular main character. And secondly - and again in 2015 - to make a movie set in London an extremely ethnically diverse city, where the only people who are not white and English are the members of a calypso band that appears occasionally as both soundtrack and Greek chorus is, to my mind, worse than inexcusable. But hey, other than that, the movie is charming.It's also, however, a bit derivative, as it opens with a cute historical scratched-print black & white documentary movie of the exploits of the (white, British) explorer who first discovers the intelligent bears of "darkest Peru," recalling the equally charming opener of Pixar's 2009 "Up." Once that intro established, we find ourselves in the jungle, years later and now in color, where those same bears - a childless male and female, who live with a young nephew - have learned to speak English (and enjoy marmalade) thanks to books and other items left behind by the aforementioned explorer. They live an idyllic (and beautifully designed) existence in a lovely tree house where they can make marmalade to their heart's content, and where their nephew (soon to be renamed Paddington) runs free and joyful. Soon, however, disaster strikes, the idyll is shattered, and the young nephew takes off for England, where, the explorer had told his aunt and uncle, the bears would always be welcome.And so our hero (voiced with perfect diction and oodles of charisma by Ben Whishaw - Q in "Skyfall") finds himself adrift in London, but not for long. A returning family of vacationers - with the wonderful Hugh Bonneville (Robert Crawley, Earl of Grantham, on "Downton Abbey") and Sally Hawkins ("Blue Jasmine") its patriarch and matriarch - finds the bear in Paddington Station, give him his new name, and take him home (ostensibly temporarily). Soon, thanks to the nefarious machinations of a mysterious villain played with great relish by a remarkably game Nicole Kidman ("Stoker"), both family and bear find themselves embroiled in a dangerous adventure. Will they survive? Well, it's a kids' movie. What do you expect?Well choreographed and with remarkable CGI effects for the bears (Paddington's fur, in particular, continued to amaze me, especially as it moved in the wind), the movie should be fun and exciting for most audiences. And if you don't mind the (probably unconscious, but no less palatable) colonial attitudes of the filmmakers, then you'll have an even better time than I did. Be sure to bring some marmalade for the little ones.

Who'd of thunk that walking, talking bears would be more civilized and less murderous than walking, talking apes? It's just one of the questions that come up during "Paddington", a movie you kinda half-watch while you're delighted that your kids have found something to distract themselves from karaoke-ing "Let it Go" from Frozen for the thousandth time. Basically it's harmless, kinda funny, and very charming. The title character is a descendant of a line of "special bears" living in a Peruvian forest, taught to talk and have a love of marmalade by a London explorer on safari. He leaves, but says that if any of the bears ever want to visit him in London, they can expect a warm welcome. Many years later when their tree-house style homes are destroyed (we expect some moralizing on deforestation but it never comes), the title character is sent away by boat to London to try and find a new one, where he meets the Brown family at Paddington station.  No one in the bustling city seems particularly baffled to see a walking, talking bear nor does anyone question it when the title character says his aunt (voiced by Imelda Staunton) and Uncle (voiced by Michael Gambon) have regular names while he has a bear name sounding something like a roar and a belch. What's it matter if it could get a quick laugh out of the kids. It's more funny than the human name he's given, Paddington (voiced by Ben Whishaw in a very gentle, genial way that makes it hard to see how originally cast Colin Firth could have possibly done the same).  The Brown family is one like many others. Mr. Brown (Downton Abbey's Hugh Bonneville, getting the best jokes and telling them with stodgy perfection) is an overprotective risk assessor whose job and worry for his children have turned him dull. His wife (Sally Hawkins) is a much more nurturing sort who convinces him to take Paddington in, despite Mr. Brown's continued reluctance. And the kids (Samuel Joslin, Madeleine Harris) are in the pre-teen stages where parents hanging around is embarrassing but having a bear around is kinda cool.  Nicole Kidman shows up here as a "Cruella DeVille" style villain after Paddington. That's about it for plot. Expect quite a bit of physical comedy (a scene where Paddington creates havoc in the Brown's bathroom is something right out of Mr. Bean), some that just feels lazy (Paddington gets wrapped up in tape), some gross stuff for the kids, and some cheesy gags like a GPS telling a driver to bare left and then...hey, there's Paddington. It's pretty sanitized comedy, thankfully stripped of any pop culture jokes or dumbed down characters.  And it's a charmer too. In one scene a character, played by James Broadbent, eloquently says that the body reaches the home quick, but "the heart takes a little longer." It's a beautiful sentiment that's easy to understand and describes the driving soul behind pretty much all of "Paddington". It might be aimed more toward kids, but it has universal themes, and it earns its lovability too much to judge it too harshly for its flaws.

began to build earlier this week when the British Board of Film Classification announced that Paddington, the new film based on Michael Bond's much-loved series of children's books, had been rated PG for "dangerous behaviour, mild threat, mild sex references and mild bad language".What on earth had happened, we wondered, to this fuzzy emblem of childhood? Had movie-stardom gone to his marmalade-tousled head? Had the grizzly turned a bit . . . well, grisly? Were we about to see Paddington bare?Call off the riots and hashtag campaigns. Here's the good news: the new version of Paddington, brought beautifully to life by Ben Whishaw and the digital artists at the visual effects house Framestore, is every bit as sweet and charming as Bond's original creation. (With respect to Colin Firth, who left the role in June after it was decided he wasn't quite right for it, Whishaw's hot-tea-and-honey voice is so ideal that it's impossible to imagine anyone else ever being considered.)Related ArticlesWATCH Paddington on the red carpet at the world premiere 19 Nov 2014Paddington Bear: picture special 10 Jun 2014Paddington producer David Heyman: 'I still have my teddy bear' 23 Nov 2014Paddington: bearing all 19 Nov 2014And now, the even better news: the film around him is a total delight, as warm and welcome as a hot pair of socks on a winter morning. It's also enormously funny in an unmistakably British way: the overall effect is something like a Children's Film Foundation adventure styled by Wes Anderson and written by Peter Cook.Because this is 2014, there's also a back-story. Paddington opens with crackling newsreel footage of an expedition to Darkest Peru, in which an explorer with a reassuring moustache, played by Tim Downie, happens on a family of bears with a liking for fruit preserves and an unexpected flair for languages. Flash forward many years, and Paddington is collecting oranges for his Aunt Lucy and Uncle Pastuzo (voiced by Imelda Staunton and Michael Gambon) to make a new batch of marmalade, when an earthquake - mild threat! - destroys the family nest.It's the nudge that our ursine hero needs to strike out on his own, and he heads via cargo ship for London: a place the explorer had promised his aunt and uncle would always extend a warm welcome to bears.The first Paddington book was published in 1958, when the image of young evacuees standing on railway platforms with a suitcase each and labels around their necks was still fresh in the British collective consciousness, and director Paul King and his co-writer Hamish McColl make sure that resonance isn't lost. It's there when Paddington first encounters the Brown family, and even more so, with an unexpected pang of sadness, when he meets the antique shop owner Mr Gruber (Jim Broadbent), a refugee of Hitler's Germany in Bond's original books, who reflects here on his own fateful journey to London that began at a railway station.It's a flash of seriousness in the middle of a typical sequence of chocolate-box fun - we've just watched a model train pop out of Mr Gruber's grandfather clock, chug its way around the parlour, then pull up on the coffee table with a boiler full of freshly brewed tea and a tender piled with sugar. But it shows how sincerely King's film has engaged with Bond's creation, and how committed it is to leaving behind a sprinkling of ideas once the hi jinks have ended.Savour, too, the film's ingenious use of Notting Hill as a setting: far from the stylishly tatty, white-upper-middle-class game preserve of Richard Curtis's frenzied imaginings, Paddington embraces the area's famous melting-pot vibrancy, which allows even a bear from a few hundred miles outside Lima to feel at home. While Paddington pads around the neighbourhood, he often crosses paths with a Cuban son band, whose music, at once brilliantly idiosyncratic and perfectly in place, chimes with the mood. "In London nobody's alike, which means everyone fits in," he muses later on, and there are worse lessons for children to learn from a film than that.But serious as Paddington is about meaning something, it's even more serious about the business of having fun. King's background in television comedy (he directed The Mighty Boosh and Come Fly With Me) clearly pays off in many sequences of precision-timed slapstick, some of which involve a very game Nicole Kidman as a fanatical taxidermist - even milder threat! - with a rare specimen in her crosshairs.Hugh Bonneville and Sally Hawkins, meanwhile, light up the whole production as Mr and Mrs Brown, two imperfect parents with transparently good intentions, and light-years removed from the annoying, uncool mother/father stereotype. They're also both very amusing: a sequence in which Bonneville infiltrates a library while dressed as a cleaning lady, and is forced to make small talk with fuckin hilarious Simon Farnaby's affectionate desk clerk (cue the gentler-than-gentle sex references, wisely downgraded last night by the BBFC to "innuendo") is pure Peter Cook, and one of the funniest things I've seen this year.The film's big finish at the Natural History Museum is perhaps a little schematic, and you long for even more Peter Capaldi as the Browns' miserable neighbour Mr Curry, but these are quibbles, not problems, and hardly take the shine off. At best, I'd hoped a Paddington film would leave me with a smile and a nostalgic tingle. I didn't expect to laugh myself half-silly and feel a renewed ache of love for the city I call home. The instruction "please look after this bear" has been heeded. Serving as one of the most critically acclaimed children's films of 2014, Paddington sounded like a delightful romp.The thing about Paddington is that it is a British film and so it's humour falls into that category. Normally I love British humour, but British children's humour is something I am new to and I didn't find it as funny as i might have hoped it would be. Part of it is that I was not familiar with the Paddington books prior to seeing the film and therefore didn't grow up with it which means that it didn't have the same relevance to me that it did to its English viewers. To put it blankly, due to unfamiliarity I was not a fan of Paddington and so the film was all new to me. I admit that I enjoyed it, but the children's book style of he film was one that took some adjusting too. Paddington handles its material like a cartoon to stay true to the storybook fashion of the source material which is impressive in some ways, but it makes the film very cheesy as well which not everyone would be able to grasp. Those who can will love the film, but it is a very child oriented feature which didn't exactly hit all the marks for me. What was weird for me was the tone of the film. Paddington is a film which tries not to take itself seriously and remain a child friendly romp, yet so much of the story seems rather serious with some dark connotations along the line. The film is the journey of a friendly talking bear as he searches for a home and deals with all kinds of strange situations along the way, and I'll admit that the nature of the storytelling was very effective. It went through the same generic sentimentality that viewers will have seen countless times before and was entertaining more when it found ways to have fun with the story instead of trying to jerk tears out of its viewers. But it all felt somewhat strange to me because I didn't know whether to take the story seriously or see it all for comic value. The inconsistent tone of the film made it a rather strange experience in some ways, and although as a whole I had appreciation for the general style and the humour, it was mostly at a sporadic rate. All I can say is that people unfamiliar with the Paddington books or who aren't accustomed to British family humour will find an all new experience in Paul King's adaptation of the 1958 character's story. Whether or not they will like it is the question.For me, Paddington was mostly a good film because of its general style. Paul King's directorial work on the film was strong because he managed to make the venture a lighthearted one, even if it went into dark territory at times. The entire time it felt like imagery coming straight out of a storybook which gave the film an effective style and a sense of life and colour. I'll admit I wasn't as amazed as I might have been if I were a child, but Paddington doesn't try to be breakthrough. It just tries to be good, and more often than not it is able to succeed. Paddington is a very good looking film with a lot of creative cinematography put in play to capture the versatile collection of scenery in the background. And imposed over the screen is strong animation used to depict the titular character Paddington with visual effects all very strong, giving the character his own organic movements and maintaining his naturally cute demeanour. The general manner in which Paddington characterises its titular character is nice because it is so gentle in its approach, ensuring that he remains a well-meaning character who succumbs to his animal tendencies occasionally as part of the film's humour. Granted, it may not always be funny, but Paddington is in fact a good character who is really lovable and has the ability to appeal to young viewers in a Winnie the Pooh type manner. Ben Whishaw manages to do a strong job voicing the character by grasping the gentle tone of voice which makes Paddington the sweet young bear that he is famous for, and he is able to get the humour and the sentimentality correct in his articulation.Although it takes a while to get into the character, Hugh Bonneville eventually makes a welcome lead for Paddington. As the main human character in the film, he makes a duo with Paddington and the two share a strong chemistry. Hugh Bonneville acts alongside Paddington as if he is more than just a creation of visual effects which is impressive, and through that any the many comic situations of the film, Hugh Bonneville manages to keep up with them very nicely. Hugh Bonneville makes a capable comic foil in Paddington.Nicole Kidman is surprisingly perfect for the role of antagonist Millicent Clyde. Though the actress has drifted in recent years, she finds a lot of energy in her role in Paddington and fits the role perfectly. As the cheesy villain of the film, Nicole Kidman uses her blank face and dead cold stare to project a sense of evil in the role. She fits the profile immaculately, remaining confident in her physical movements and delivering her lines with strong voice articulation. Nicole Kidman is able to embrace the childish style of Paddington and just go with it, making it one of her finer performances from recent years.Sally Hawkins projects a likable presence, and Matt Lucas' cameo was a nice touch, though I say that as a fan of Little Britain.So although Paddington is a bit much on the sentimentality and inconsistent in terms of tone, it is a stylish film which is funny enough to entertain and features strong visual effects as well as a talented array of cast members lined up to perform.

Good natured and clumsy bear from Darkest Peru lands himself in London after an earthquake kills his uncle; his ageing auntie sends him there to look for relatives of the explorer that visited the area and befriended them both years ago. The Browns, a family of Londoners, find him alone and vulnerable in Paddington and "adopt him" and rename him after the popular station. He brings with him disorganization, kindness and love to marmalade and everything British. The crash with the tidy lives of the Browns is remarkable and comic. But somebody else in London is looking for him, taxidermist Millicent wants to find extraordinary obscure new species of animals to stuff and display at the Natural History Museum...An engaging film for the young ones with funny slapstick scenes of utter chaos and destruction and tender and heart-warming dialogues full of charm; children are going to love it and adults will too just as soon as they get past the talking bear that doesn't need a Visa to reside in Britain. The story is well concocted and entertaining but simple enough for the kids to follow. Don't miss it in the cinema.

Paddington is a hugely cherised character, so making a live-action film of the most adorable bear in the world has been quite a risk. Forunately director Paul King has clearly an immense amount of reverence for the furball, and in terms of the character itself the film succeeds admirably. The animation is lively and beautiful, and Ben Whishaw's vocal performance is wonderful. But everything else around the character is amiss, like Sally Hawkins' annoying performance, Nicole Kidman's cartoonish villain, Jim Broadbent's awfully goofy accent, and the excessive mawkishness. There are only a couple truly funny jokes, but mostly the humor is uninspired and the old lessons about taking care of outcasts and learning to accept different people as who they are all too familiar. Paddington is one of those family comedies that will certainly appeal to children, but grown-up audiences will find disappointment. Nostalgia won't help either.

I had no intention to see this until the wonderful reviews begin to roll in - it was No.20 in Time Out's Films of 2014! So off I went, still with some trepidation as, let's face it, I nor my companions are the target audience for this film... and I was proven right. While the film is a very decent adaptation of the beloved book/TV series, retaining and winking knowingly at all the details that made the original so endearing; even with an above average stab at the CGI bear, it never transcends being a nice British film for the kids. It is sweet and polite with a decent cast of British thesps and comedians doing respectable turns and a mild menace in the form of a gamed Nicole Kidman playing a second-hand Cruella de Vil. The drama is never too engaging and the comedy is more slapstick and clumsy tomfoolery. The best thing here is the imaginative and colourful art and set designs and while Ben Whishaw doing the voice of Paddington is probably a prudent last minute change (I simply cannot imagine what the Colin Firth version would sound like) but at times it does feel like I'm listening to Q narrating the film.

With the Christmas holidays upon us, so too is an array of kiddie-friendly flicks, beginning with this very British adventure designed to adore the socks off kids and adults alike. Based on the immensely popular talking bear of the title, this modern update could have been saccharine, morally burdensome and unbearable for anyone older than 8. But in striking a fantastic balance between old-fashioned innocence and contemporary sensibilities, writer-director Paul King has dished up a motion picture that is fun, light-hearted and just plain sweet. He's helped by a game cast: be it the affable pair of Hugh Bonneville and Sally Hawkins as Paddington's adopted guardians, the gleefully menacing Nicole Kidman as a malevolent taxidermist, or amusing old- timers Julie Walters and Jim Broadbent who light up the screen with their eclectic supporting characters. Yet nobody can outshine the cute little fur-ball at the centre of proceedings. Voiced by Ben Whishaw (after an 11th hour change from Colin Firth) and carefully crafted with CGI, ol' Paddy is utterly delightful and a wonderful companion for 95 minutes. There are flaws to be found and the laughs may not come thick and fast, but Paddington will melt the heart of even the toughest cynic.

As a growing up kid with the love for reading (staying near a library helped alot), I did stumble upon this talking bear who wears a red hat & blue coat about twice or thrice, mainly the upon insistence of my dad, in order to prevent me from the usual DC/Marvel comic books I use to pick up. Back in 2007, when the film was first announced, I was generally confused about the direction the film would take, & having seen other animated kid friendly characters turning into live action disasters such as Alvin & The Chipmunks series (Even though the 1st wasn't all that bad, the sequels oh god no!), The Smurfs, Marmaduke, Garfield etc, made me more reluctant and hesitant as to what I was due to view; Colin Firth's dropping from the project added to my concerns. To my joy, the film was very far from a disaster! Indeed, its one of the most delightful family films I have seen in a while. The story begins in Darkest Peru, where a young bear (voiced perfectly by Ben Whishaw) lives happily with his Aunt Lucy (Imelda Staunton) and Uncle Pastuzo (Michael Gambon). He inherits from them a healthy love for marmalade and London, as well as a floppy, red felt hat left behind decades ago by English explorer Montgomery Clyde. When an earthquake destroys their idyllic home, Aunt Lucy urges her nephew to strike out to London. Many jars of marmalade later, he finds himself in the iconic train station that gives him his name. He meets the Brown family: risk- averse Henry (Hugh Bonneville), lovely Mary (Sally Hawkins) and their children, Judy (Madeleine Harris) and Jonathan (Samuel Joslin). With Henry insisting that Paddington can only stay while he looks for a more permanent home, the bear begins investigations in London - unaware that Millicent, an obsessive, crazy taxidermist (Nicole Kidman), has very specific reasons for wanting him to visit her museum while enlisting help of the Brown family's weird neighbor Mr Curry (Peter Capaldi). The CGI representation of our titular bear is wonderfully delightful. His expressions and mannerisms are spot on. Strictly speaking, there isn't anything all that new or original about Paddington. We've seen the trope many times before - in trying to find a new home, a misfit changes the hearts and minds of the people who will eventually become his family. The narrative of the film is also little more than a patchwork of wacky accidents: the bathroom flooding scene; apprehension of a pick pocket; the infiltrate the top-secret Geographers' Guild. And yet, King has crafted something quite charming and magical around the bare bones of his story. He has updated and deepened the story to give the elder Browns their own emotional arc rather than just focusing on the bear. Most importantly, King has infused the entire film with joyous strains of comedy, slight gags, wit & parodies of other works. The sharp script and stunning visuals would mean little without an accomplished cast - Hugh Bonneville & Sally Hawkins are the soul of the film, its pretty clear they were enjoying themselves enormously. However, Nicole Kidman is the ultimate scene stealer. Her good looks & maniac performance reminds us how an actress can still remain wonderful even after so many years despite a string of flops. Peter Capaldi (Doctor Who) gets his own hilarious moments as well. Director Paul King has given us a story that is simple and easy to follow, but full of momentum. The characters are all well-drawn, sympathetic, and well played. On the whole 'Paddington' is a very well-executed adaptation of the titular bear for a 21st century audience. Its a perfect family friendly film which is heart-warming and humorous without being too over-sentimental. It doesn't matter whether you're a fan of the books, or someone who knew only the cuddly soft toy or the animated escapades, Paddington is a big, warm bear hug of a film, that will surely delight fans of all ages.

"It doesn't matter that he's a different species, or that he has a worrying marmalade problem; Paddington is family."Perhaps the most surprising cinematic endeavour this year was Paul King's entertaining adaptation of the classic Michael Bond character named Paddington; a talking bear who has an unusual taste for marmalade and is taken in by a human family (the Browns) at Paddington station in London. Whilst somewhat conventional in its premise and plot, the film contains heart and charm to spare, the titular character particularly likable in all instances. This is what separates Paddington from many of this years distasteful and unsatisfactory kids films; not only is their humour utterly juvenile, but the characters are not full of heart or humanity. Perhaps Paddington's best asset is the fact that the entire film is filled to the brim with heart and warmth, the primary protagonist and his foster family having a suitable and enjoyable progression throughout the film, that whilst undeniably cliched, is still wholly entertaining.The film centres around Paddington and how after an earthquake in his home of darkest Peru, one which unfortunately kills his uncle, he is sent to live in London by his auntie. The talking bear travels to the capital of Britain, and is taken in by the initially reluctant but somewhat welcoming Brown family, who seek to acquaint Paddington with the explorer who originally taught his auntie and uncle how to speak English, and promised them that they would be welcome in his home country. Meanwhile, a villainous taxidermist seeks to stuff Paddington and receive acclaim for showcasing the intelligent bear to the world.Perhaps the biggest issue going against Paddington from the onset is that the central story is nothing overtly new for a kids film; a foreigner entering a new landscape and finding numerous cultural differences from what he'd been led to believe were accepted is nothing that we haven't seen before. The atrocious Garfield 2, to a certain degree, possessed a relatively similar plot line, and that movie was condemned by the vast majority who saw it. The difference between Paddington and that children's picture is that the former possesses not only far more accessible and enjoyable jokes, but provides a stronger and more sympathetic central character, as well as side characters who possess stereotypical attributes which are nevertheless entertaining to watch play out. We can't help but feel for Paddington within the first few minutes of the film as his uncle is killed; our heart goes out to this poor and innocent creature who has to suddenly move away from his home and go into a foreign country where no one, at first, appears to sport any concern for his well-being. His naivety is a stark contrast to many kids films which possess self-centred or overly-confident characters; often these characters are unlikable or faulted to a major point. Paddington's best asset is his naive and childlike sense of adventure; not only does it provide material for numerous hilarious sequences, but it allows his character to become far more accessible and sympathetic.The Brown family are no less enjoyable to watch, their fumbling and awkward ways undeniably entertaining, even considering the idea that they conform to numerous genericisms throughout. The mother of the family, played by Sally Hawkins, is the sympathetic, helpless but caring individual who is required to convince the family of the necessity of taking home Paddington when they find him at the train station; the father, played by Hugh Bonneville, is the stern and initially insensitive man who eventually comes round to Paddington, and learns to have fun with those around him; the daughter, played by Madeleine Harris, is the easily embarrassed girl who feels a need to fit in at any cost; the son, played by Samuel Joslin, is the adventurous and incautious boy who enjoys running around and playing with Paddington, and finally, the elder of the household, played by Julie Brown, is the unusually fun and amusing older individual who acts more like a child than any of the children. None of these characters are particularly new, fresh or invigorating. They continually appeal to conventions that are both irritable and boring. Yet still, it's their relationship with Paddington, the actors and actresses behind the characters and their eventual character arc that sees them inviting laughs and approval from the audience; even one that includes numerous cynical teenagers, such as the group that I was accompanied to the film with.The humour itself is absolutely fantastic; whilst there are brief instances of slapstick humour, the picture as a whole features jokes which are practical, ironic and unexpectedly mature for the film and its rating. The comeuppance against Nicole Kidman's evil character Millicent not only rendered reduced my friends and I to boisterous laughter, but proved undeniably testing of the 'G' rating the film had earned. Very few of the film's central pieces of humour are unforeshadowed or entirely sudden in nature, the screenwriters taking care to build up each individual joke or moment to pay off more for the viewer. Paddington himself is perhaps the funniest component of the film, his attempts to adapt to the modern British way of life both hapless, sympathetic and often incredibly amusing, but never tiresome. None of the jokes feel re-hashed, and when a previously used piece of humour returns to the forefront, it is not blatantly recycled. The diversity and range of the humour installed within this film is undoubtedly its most crowd-pleasing feature.The film's cinematography, visuals and music are all undeniably effective in instilling a warmness that the film was beckoning for. The unique visuals and clever techniques to make the film stand out among the general mish-mash of cinematic drivel within this genre are engaging and applaudable, cinematographer Erik Wilson (responsible for the unique visual style of another popular British 2014 picture; Richard Ayoade's The Double) giving the film an intimate feel. His beautiful camera work within the initial scenes in darkest Peru, which feature the gorgeous bears and their environment in the most stunning ways possible. When Paddington comes to London, the film becomes far more intimate and low-angled, accenting Paddington's size in comparison to the rest of the city. Paddington is brought to life thanks to competent computer generated imagery from Framestore and animatronics, by Nick Dudman. Whilst the CGI showcased within the film is most certainly not as impressive as that which was shown within pictures like Dawn of the Planet of the Apes or Interstellar earlier in the year, the CGI is strong enough to allow the audience member to get caught up in the character and his plights, and very rarely takes the audience member out from the immediate danger or event. Considering this is one of the goals of CGI, acclamation is deserved by those who undertook the challenging process of bringing the cuddly, adorable titular character to life.The score, composed by Nick Urata, is docile, orthodox and nothing unique, but what it does contain, like the rest of the film, is a warmth and homeliness that is highly appreciated. Utilizing instrumentation and thematic material which lacks subtlety but preserves the emotion and basic characterisation of those who litter the film, Urata is part of the formula for Paddington which makes it so damn enjoyable. The film isn't as intelligent or energetic as some of the best animations or kids films released within this year of cinema, such as How To Train Your Dragon 2, The Lego Movie or The Boxtrolls, but what it lacks in originality and distinctness it makes up for in plain fun and humour. Paddington is one of the more entertaining pictures I've seen this year, and speaking with those who were with me during our screening, should be universally appreciated. I can only anticipate that the most cynical, cold and disdainful of viewers could possibly loathe or even dislike this enjoyable picture. I can't wait to revisit this fantastic film!"What this family needed was a pinch of chaos!"

With the Christmas holidays upon us, so too is an array of kiddie-friendly flicks, beginning with this very British adventure designed to adore the socks off kids and adults alike. Based on the immensely popular talking bear of the title, this modern update could have been saccharine, morally burdensome and unbearable for anyone older than 8. But in striking a fantastic balance between old-fashioned innocence and contemporary sensibilities, writer-director Paul King has dished up a motion picture that is fun, light-hearted and just plain sweet. He's helped by a game cast: be it the affable pair of Hugh Bonneville and Sally Hawkins as Paddington's adopted guardians, the gleefully menacing Nicole Kidman as a malevolent taxidermist, or amusing old-timers Julie Walters and Jim Broadbent who light up the screen with their eclectic supporting characters. Yet nobody can outshine the cute little fur-ball at the centre of proceedings. Voiced by Ben Whishaw (after an 11th hour change from Colin Firth) and carefully crafted with CGI, ol' Paddy is utterly delightful and a wonderful companion for 95 minutes. There are flaws to be found and the laughs may not come thick and fast, but Paddington will melt the heart of even the toughest cynic.

A wonderful adaptation drawn from the characters immortalised in the books, this film is a major success. Heart-warming and humorous without being mawkish or over-sentimental, the antics and escapades of lovable Paddington Bear will surely delight fans of all ages. How the animators achieved such a wonderful and memorable 'Paddington' is a minor miracle. His expressions and mannerisms are spot on, whilst the cast are obviously all enjoying themselves enormously in being permitted to perform in Paddington's World. It is obvious that a great deal of love and affection has been injected into the making of this film; the acting, graphics, editing, sets and storyline are all virtually flawless, and you must surely be a soul with no heart not to find some modicum of pleasure from this 90 minute magical movie experience.I have deducted one star, which may seem a tad mean after such a glowing review, but that is simply because my family and I wanted the film to go on longer. And that is a sure sign of a good movie.

I have to state this before continuing with this review, prior to seeing this I was very reluctant and hesitant as to what I was due to view. After growing up hearing the stories and watching the animated tales of Paddington Bear, I was unsure as to whether a CGI-heavy live-action tale could really establish a story that portrays the bear in all his charm, well my predictions were woefully inaccurate. 'Paddington' is a very well-executed adaptation of the titular bear for a 21st century audience. From the producers of Harry Potter, 'Paddington' delivers a family-friendly and charming atmosphere whilst conveying an endearing and gloriously comedic tale about a bear and his adventures in London. One of the late and great films of the year, Paul King's irresistibly warm story creates a sense of nostalgia whilst boasting a quintessentially British feel and pitch-perfect humour that can be enjoyed by people of all ages.

Do you just hate it when a trailer or a movie poster can false advertise a movie like: Edge of tomorrow, Dredd 3-D, Warm Bodies and now this movie.The story to Paddington is about a Peruvian bear who loves all things British, travels to London only to find himself overwhelmed at Paddington station. Lucky for him, the Brown family discovers him and offers a temporary haven. But he also catches the eye of a museum taxidermist, who is determined to add the rare bear to his collection.The first teaser trailer for this movie was in my opinion god-awful, you know when he's in the bathroom and he puts the two tooth brushes in his ears and gives it a little bit of a twist and turn, then he pulls it out and you can clearly see a giant peace of ear wax and then he licks it; that right they is just stupid kids humor and I wasn't looking forward to film at all. But when I look at some of the reviews for the film it actually got good feed back from critics. Empire give the film a five out of five star's and IGN give the film a 7.9/10, I couldn't believe it, I had to check twice to make sure that what I'm seeing is true, but I still wasn't hooked until I got a chance to see the film and to my surprise the movie isn't as bad as I thought it was and I actually found the movie to be funny. Ben Whishaw did the voice for the marmalade loving bear himself Paddington, and Ben Whishaw did a outstanding job of playing Paddington. He had that voice of a young, friendly and kind person (or bear if you must). Now originally Colin Firth was suppose to play this role but at the last minute he turned the role down by saying, "The voice didn't match the character ", and to be honest I think he did the right thing, because I don't Firth's voice will match the character at all he just sound like Colin Firth.The movie has beautiful cinematography with some breathtaking shots of London, and the film had the Christmas feeling to it and it actually got the tone right.Now the visual effect's for the bear I have to be honest was the most realistic thing I've seen since this years movie Dawn Of the planet of the Apes. His fur looks like real fur that I can just go up to the screen a feel it, then I get kicked out the cinema for being a weirdo, but as I said realistic.If I had to pick a thing that I didn't like about the film I would say the character's and some of the jokes sometimes hit and sometimes miss. The character's in the movie are not all that interesting and they pretty dull to watch, Paddington, Nicole Kidman and Peter Capaldi are the only character's that I actually liked, and yes even the villain I enjoyed watching more then the family. Some of the jokes at times mash really well and didn't but when I think that's a small complain.Overall Paddinton was the biggest surprise of the year for me with it's cute bear, nice story and overall a good family film.

Based on the beloved character from novels by Michael Bond, Paddington tells the story of the young Peruvian bear who travels to London in search of a new home. The eponymous bear's adventure begins in darkest Peru where an explorer promises the native talking bears a warm welcome if they ever visit London. However, by the time an earthquake forces one of them to embark on this journey, many years have passed and the city is not what he had imagined.Producer David Heyman is no stranger to bringing beloved characters from pages to the big screen after being involved in the Harry Potter franchise, and Paddington may jolly well become a start of a new franchise. Everywhere Paddington goes, chaos follows. From bathroom flooding, escalator and skate board riding to sticky tape, the cuddly bear cannot do anything right at the start. Scenes filled with witty gags (and action inspired by Mission Impossible) are plenty. The clever script is executed to perfection by the cast. In particular, Hugh Bonneville as Mr. Brown, an uptight risk analyst to unlikely hero, is a delight in every scene he is in. Nicole Kidman, channeling Cruella De Vil to a glorious performance, is the taxidermist Millicent Clyde determined to add stuffed Paddington to her collection. Best of them all, Ben Whishaw gives Paddington a voice that is innocent, wistful and yet determined that allows the bear to stay in the limelight.In all, very much like Stuart Little, Paddington touches on the theme of fitting in without sacrificing the essential charms of a family-friendly movie. As sweet as a marmalade sandwich for dire emergency, this film is the very definition of a pleasant surprise and will no doubt, enchant children of all ages. Please go watch this bear. Thank you.

"Always keep a Marmalade sandwich under your hat for emergencies."Re-introducing a beloved children's character is difficult. As we've seen recently with train-wrecks like 'Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles' and past miss-steps like 'Garfield' it can be hard to make it relevant and in the former's case even competent. 'Paddington' is one I'd been watching for a while now and despite a solid trailer I still held a certain amount of scepticism towards it. Having been burned so many times in the past with classic characters I prepared for teh worst. I needn't worry as 'Paddington' is a truly worthy entry in the character's long history. A universal story of finding somewhere to fit and the stranger in a foreign land coming to grips with the way of the world in their new home. Starting in the darkest Peru 'Paddington' (Ben Wishaw) get's a nice small (and needed) back-story to his reasons for coming to London. It immediately establishes a tone that told me "No this isn't pandering to the dimmest bulb in the room' - with some surprising wit. It's an easy going movie with a nice steady pace that suites it to a tea. The film seems to serve (at least to me) as an introduction to the character, giving the impression that this isn't the last we'll see of him. He still has the marmalade obsession as well as the iconic hat and later on the blue coat. He's very much teh same character something other re-introductions of past characters seemed to have neglected. Opting instead for a new personality when the character being the character is why he's so beloved - something the writer clearly knows here. Paddington's story is still has endearing an heart-warming as ever without the cringyness that can usually come attached. Updating the setting to the London of today while keeping the essence, there's also a cartoon-esque feel to some of the scenes that is very welcome and an equally cartoon villain - that doesn't show up or stay long but still makes a decent impact. It's not a laugh riot and some of the jokes fall flat to me - as well as 'Mrs.Bird' who comes of as an irritant to me as well as the films only source of cringe.Bringing the message of fitting in, into a modern London and bringing 'Paddington' as a character with it as well - while still keeping the core of what makes him some loved. 'Paddington' is a certain success and a rare good even great Christmas movie. Directed with a whimsical style and written with a wit not usually seen in children movies, this certainly isn't part of the horrible classic character updates. Paddington' is a certain success and possible future children's classic.

OK it's made for kids but adults will enjoy the humour in this too and they've done an amazing job creating a believable Paddington Bear. The London in the film isn't the one I'm familiar with but that's not surprising as it's made by the same team that made Harry Potter so the film has the same sheen. Bonneville is great as Mr Brown and is ably supported by Hawkins as his kooky spouse. The only sour note comes from Kidman as Paddington's nemesis and her story seems at odds with the charm of the rest of the film. Besides that I think Paddington is a bit of a triumph and I wouldn't be surprised to see a sequel in the pipeline soon.

Enchanting and endearing; its hard not to fall in love with this little Peruvian bear. Adapting Paddington's domestic escapades to the big screen was always going to be a risk, but its been achieved brilliantly! All the quirks and charms Britain fell in love with all those years ago remain and, as some may fear, aren't lost in the special effects of the film. In fact, they are amplified by these very effects which are woven into the story in ways that transport you back to your childhood to give it that heart-warmingly nostalgic boost! I already want to see it again!
